member.summary: A structure that contains input information for a canary run.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryRunConfigInput.ActiveTracing
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ActiveTracing.
Specifies whether this canary is to use active X-Ray tracing when it runs. Active tracing enables this canary run to be displayed in the ServiceLens and X-Ray service maps even if the canary does not hit an endpoint that has X-Ray tracing enabled. Using X-Ray tracing incurs charges. For more information, see Canaries and X-Ray tracing.
You can enable active tracing only for canaries that use version syn-nodejs-2.0 or later for their canary runtime.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryRunConfigInput.EnvironmentVariables
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EnvironmentVariables.
Specifies the keys and values to use for any environment variables used in the canary script. Use the following format:
{ "key1" : "value1", "key2" : "value2", ...}
Keys must start with a letter and be at least two characters. The total size of your environment variables cannot exceed 4 KB. You can't specify any Lambda reserved environment variables as the keys for your environment variables. For more information about reserved keys, see Runtime environment variables.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryRunConfigInput.MemoryInMB
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MemoryInMB.
The maximum amount of memory available to the canary while it is running, in MB. This value must be a multiple of 64.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryRunConfigInput.TimeoutInSeconds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TimeoutInSeconds.
How long the canary is allowed to run before it must stop. You can't set this time to be longer than the frequency of the runs of this canary.
If you omit this field, the frequency of the canary is used as this value, up to a maximum of 14 minutes.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryScheduleInput
member.summary: This structure specifies how often a canary is to make runs and the date and time when it should stop making runs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryScheduleInput.DurationInSeconds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DurationInSeconds.
How long, in seconds, for the canary to continue making regular runs according to the schedule in the Expression value. If you specify 0, the canary continues making runs until you stop it. If you omit this field, the default of 0 is used.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryScheduleInput.Expression
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Expression.
A rate expression or a cron expression that defines how often the canary is to run.
For a rate expression, The syntax is rate(number unit). unit can be minute, minutes, or hour.
For example, rate(1 minute) runs the canary once a minute, rate(10 minutes) runs it once every 10 minutes, and rate(1 hour) runs it once every hour. You can specify a frequency between rate(1 minute) and rate(1 hour).
Specifying rate(0 minute) or rate(0 hour) is a special value that causes the canary to run only once when it is started.
Use cron(expression) to specify a cron expression. You can't schedule a canary to wait for more than a year before running. For information about the syntax for cron expressions, see Scheduling canary runs using cron.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryScheduleOutput
member.summary: How long, in seconds, for the canary to continue making regular runs according to the schedule in the Expression value.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryScheduleOutput.DurationInSeconds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DurationInSeconds.
How long, in seconds, for the canary to continue making regular runs after it was created. The runs are performed according to the schedule in the Expression value.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CanaryScheduleOutput.Expression
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Expression.
A rate expression or a cron expression that defines how often the canary is to run.
For a rate expression, The syntax is rate(number unit). unit can be minute, minutes, or hour.
For example, rate(1 minute) runs the canary once a minute, rate(10 minutes) runs it once every 10 minutes, and rate(1 hour) runs it once every hour. You can specify a frequency between rate(1 minute) and rate(1 hour).
Specifying rate(0 minute) or rate(0 hour) is a special value that causes the canary to run only once when it is started.
Use cron(expression) to specify a cron expression. For information about the syntax for cron expressions, see Scheduling canary runs using cron.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateCanary operation. Creates a canary. Canaries are scripts that monitor your endpoints and APIs from the outside-in. Canaries help you check the availability and latency of your web services and troubleshoot anomalies by investigating load time data, screenshots of the UI, logs, and metrics. You can set up a canary to run continuously or just once.
Do not use CreateCanary to modify an existing canary. Use UpdateCanary instead.
To create canaries, you must have the CloudWatchSyntheticsFullAccess policy. If you are creating a new IAM role for the canary, you also need the the iam:CreateRole, iam:CreatePolicy and iam:AttachRolePolicy permissions. For more information, see Necessary Roles and Permissions.
Do not include secrets or proprietary information in your canary names. The canary name makes up part of the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the canary, and the ARN is included in outbound calls over the internet. For more information, see Security Considerations for Synthetics Canaries.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.ArtifactConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ArtifactConfig.
A structure that contains the configuration for canary artifacts, including the encryption-at-rest settings for artifacts that the canary uploads to Amazon S3.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.ArtifactS3Location
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ArtifactS3Location.
The location in Amazon S3 where Synthetics stores artifacts from the test runs of this canary. Artifacts include the log file, screenshots, and HAR files. The name of the S3 bucket can't include a period (.).

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.Code
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Code.
A structure that includes the entry point from which the canary should start running your script. If the script is stored in an S3 bucket, the bucket name, key, and version are also included.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.ExecutionRoleArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionRoleArn.
The ARN of the IAM role to be used to run the canary. This role must already exist, and must include lambda.amazonaws.com as a principal in the trust policy. The role must also have the following permissions:
s3:PutObject
s3:GetBucketLocation
s3:ListAllMyBuckets
cloudwatch:PutMetricData
logs:CreateLogGroup
logs:CreateLogStream
logs:PutLogEvents

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.FailureRetentionPeriodInDays
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FailureRetentionPeriodInDays.
The number of days to retain data about failed runs of this canary. If you omit this field, the default of 31 days is used. The valid range is 1 to 455 days.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name for this canary. Be sure to give it a descriptive name that distinguishes it from other canaries in your account.
Do not include secrets or proprietary information in your canary names. The canary name makes up part of the canary ARN, and the ARN is included in outbound calls over the internet. For more information, see Security Considerations for Synthetics Canaries.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.RunConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RunConfig.
A structure that contains the configuration for individual canary runs, such as timeout value.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.RuntimeVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RuntimeVersion.
Specifies the runtime version to use for the canary. For a list of valid runtime versions and more information about runtime versions, see Canary Runtime Versions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.Schedule
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Schedule.
A structure that contains information about how often the canary is to run and when these test runs are to stop.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.SuccessRetentionPeriodInDays
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SuccessRetentionPeriodInDays.
The number of days to retain data about successful runs of this canary. If you omit this field, the default of 31 days is used. The valid range is 1 to 455 days.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
A list of key-value pairs to associate with the canary. You can associate as many as 50 tags with a canary.
Tags can help you organize and categorize your resources. You can also use them to scope user permissions, by granting a user permission to access or change only the resources that have certain tag values.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest.VpcConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property VpcConfig.
If this canary is to test an endpoint in a VPC, this structure contains information about the subnet and security groups of the VPC endpoint. For more information, see
Running a Canary in a VPC.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.DeleteCanaryRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DeleteCanary operation. Permanently deletes the specified canary.
When you delete a canary, resources used and created by the canary are not automatically deleted. After you delete a canary that you do not intend to use again, you should also delete the following:
The Lambda functions and layers used by this canary. These have the prefix cwsyn-MyCanaryName .
The CloudWatch alarms created for this canary. These alarms have a name of Synthetics-SharpDrop-Alarm-MyCanaryName .
Amazon S3 objects and buckets, such as the canary's artifact location.
IAM roles created for the canary. If they were created in the console, these roles have the name role/service-role/CloudWatchSyntheticsRole-MyCanaryName .
CloudWatch Logs log groups created for the canary. These logs groups have the name /aws/lambda/cwsyn-MyCanaryName .
Before you delete a canary, you might want to use GetCanary to display the information about this canary. Make note of the information returned by this operation so that you can delete these resources after you delete the canary.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.DeleteCanaryRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the canary that you want to delete. To find the names of your canaries, use DescribeCanaries.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.DeleteCanaryResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteCanary operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.DescribeCanariesLastRunRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DescribeCanariesLastRun operation. Use this operation to see information from the most recent run of each canary that you have created.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.DescribeCanariesLastRunRequest.MaxResults

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.DescribeCanariesRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DescribeCanaries operation. This operation returns a list of the canaries in your account, along with full details about each canary.
This operation does not have resource-level authorization, so if a user is able to use DescribeCanaries, the user can see all of the canaries in the account. A deny policy can only be used to restrict access to all canaries. It cannot be used on specific resources.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.RuntimeVersion
member.summary: This structure contains information about one canary runtime version. For more information about runtime versions, see Canary Runtime Versions.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.RuntimeVersion.DeprecationDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeprecationDate.
If this runtime version is deprecated, this value is the date of deprecation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.RuntimeVersion.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
A description of the runtime version, created by Amazon.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.RuntimeVersion.ReleaseDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ReleaseDate.
The date that the runtime version was released.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.RuntimeVersion.VersionName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property VersionName.
The name of the runtime version. For a list of valid runtime versions, see Canary Runtime Versions.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.S3EncryptionConfig
member.summary:
A structure that contains the configuration of encryption-at-rest settings for canary artifacts that the canary uploads to Amazon S3.
For more information, see Encrypting canary artifacts

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.S3EncryptionConfig.EncryptionMode
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EncryptionMode.
The encryption method to use for artifacts created by this canary. Specify SSE_S3 to use server-side encryption (SSE) with an Amazon S3-managed key. Specify SSE-KMS to use server-side encryption with a customer-managed KMS key.
If you omit this parameter, an Amazon Web Services-managed KMS key is used.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.S3EncryptionConfig.KmsKeyArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property KmsKeyArn.
The ARN of the customer-managed KMS key to use, if you specify SSE-KMS for EncryptionMode

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StartCanaryRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the StartCanary operation. Use this operation to run a canary that has already been created. The frequency of the canary runs is determined by the value of the canary's Schedule. To see a canary's schedule, use GetCanary.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StartCanaryRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the canary that you want to run. To find canary names, use DescribeCanaries.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StartCanaryResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the StartCanary operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StopCanaryRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the StopCanary operation. Stops the canary to prevent all future runs. If the canary is currently running, Synthetics stops waiting for the current run of the specified canary to complete. The run that is in progress completes on its own, publishes metrics, and uploads artifacts, but it is not recorded in Synthetics as a completed run.
You can use StartCanary to start it running again with the canary’s current schedule at any point in the future.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StopCanaryRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the canary that you want to stop. To find the names of your canaries, use DescribeCanaries.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StopCanaryResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the StopCanary operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.TagResourceRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the TagResource operation. Assigns one or more tags (key-value pairs) to the specified canary.
Tags can help you organize and categorize your resources. You can also use them to scope user permissions, by granting a user permission to access or change only resources with certain tag values.
Tags don't have any semantic meaning to Amazon Web Services and are interpreted strictly as strings of characters.
You can use the TagResource action with a canary that already has tags. If you specify a new tag key for the alarm, this tag is appended to the list of tags associated with the alarm. If you specify a tag key that is already associated with the alarm, the new tag value that you specify replaces the previous value for that tag.
You can associate as many as 50 tags with a canary.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.TagResourceRequest.ResourceArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceArn.
The ARN of the canary that you're adding tags to.
The ARN format of a canary is arn:aws:synthetics:Region:account-id:canary:canary-name .

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.TagResourceRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
The list of key-value pairs to associate with the canary.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.TagResourceResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the TagResource operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UntagResourceRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the UntagResource operation. Removes one or more tags from the specified canary.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UntagResourceRequest.ResourceArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceArn.
The ARN of the canary that you're removing tags from.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UpdateCanaryRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the UpdateCanary operation. Use this operation to change the settings of a canary that has already been created.
You can't use this operation to update the tags of an existing canary. To change the tags of an existing canary, use TagResource.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UpdateCanaryRequest.ArtifactConfig
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ArtifactConfig.
A structure that contains the configuration for canary artifacts, including the encryption-at-rest settings for artifacts that the canary uploads to Amazon S3.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UpdateCanaryRequest.ArtifactS3Location
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ArtifactS3Location.
The location in Amazon S3 where Synthetics stores artifacts from the test runs of this canary. Artifacts include the log file, screenshots, and HAR files. The name of the S3 bucket can't include a period (.).

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UpdateCanaryRequest.Code
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Code.
A structure that includes the entry point from which the canary should start running your script. If the script is stored in an S3 bucket, the bucket name, key, and version are also included.

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UpdateCanaryRequest.ExecutionRoleArn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionRoleArn.
The ARN of the IAM role to be used to run the canary. This role must already exist, and must include lambda.amazonaws.com as a principal in the trust policy. The role must also have the following permissions:
s3:PutObject
s3:GetBucketLocation
s3:ListAllMyBuckets
cloudwatch:PutMetricData
logs:CreateLogGroup
logs:CreateLogStream
logs:CreateLogStream

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.UpdateCanaryRequest.FailureRetentionPeriodInDays

member.name: P:Amazon.Synthetics.Model.VisualReferenceInput.BaseCanaryRunId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BaseCanaryRunId.
Specifies which canary run to use the screenshots from as the baseline for future visual monitoring with this canary. Valid values are nextrun to use the screenshots from the next run after this update is made, lastrun to use the screenshots from the most recent run before this update was made, or the value of Id in the CanaryRun from any past run of this canary.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.AmazonSyntheticsClient
member.summary:
Implementation for accessing Synthetics
Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics
You can use Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics to continually monitor your services. You can create and manage canaries, which are modular, lightweight scripts that monitor your endpoints and APIs from the outside-in. You can set up your canaries to run 24 hours a day, once per minute. The canaries help you check the availability and latency of your web services and troubleshoot anomalies by investigating load time data, screenshots of the UI, logs, and metrics. The canaries seamlessly integrate with CloudWatch ServiceLens to help you trace the causes of impacted nodes in your applications. For more information, see Using ServiceLens to Monitor the Health of Your Applications in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.
Before you create and manage canaries, be aware of the security considerations. For more information, see Security Considerations for Synthetics Canaries.

member.name: M:Amazon.Synthetics.AmazonSyntheticsClient.CreateCanary(Amazon.Synthetics.Model.CreateCanaryRequest)
member.summary:
Creates a canary. Canaries are scripts that monitor your endpoints and APIs from the outside-in. Canaries help you check the availability and latency of your web services and troubleshoot anomalies by investigating load time data, screenshots of the UI, logs, and metrics. You can set up a canary to run continuously or just once.
Do not use CreateCanary to modify an existing canary. Use UpdateCanary instead.
To create canaries, you must have the CloudWatchSyntheticsFullAccess policy. If you are creating a new IAM role for the canary, you also need the the iam:CreateRole, iam:CreatePolicy and iam:AttachRolePolicy permissions. For more information, see Necessary Roles and Permissions.
Do not include secrets or proprietary information in your canary names. The canary name makes up part of the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the canary, and the ARN is included in outbound calls over the internet. For more information, see Security Considerations for Synthetics Canaries.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the CreateCanary service method.
member.returns: The response from the CreateCanary service method, as returned by Synthetics.
member.exception: An unknown internal error occurred.
A parameter could not be validated.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for CreateCanary Operation

member.summary:

You can set up a canary to run continuously or just once.

member.summary:
Permanently deletes the specified canary.
When you delete a canary, resources used and created by the canary are not automatically deleted. After you delete a canary that you do not intend to use again, you should also delete the following:
The Lambda functions and layers used by this canary. These have the prefix cwsyn-MyCanaryName .
The CloudWatch alarms created for this canary. These alarms have a name of Synthetics-SharpDrop-Alarm-MyCanaryName .
Amazon S3 objects and buckets, such as the canary's artifact location.
IAM roles created for the canary. If they were created in the console, these roles have the name role/service-role/CloudWatchSyntheticsRole-MyCanaryName .
CloudWatch Logs log groups created for the canary. These logs groups have the name /aws/lambda/cwsyn-MyCanaryName .
Before you delete a canary, you might want to use GetCanary to display the information about this canary. Make note of the information returned by this operation so that you can delete these resources after you delete the canary.

member.name: M:Amazon.Synthetics.AmazonSyntheticsClient.StopCanary(Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StopCanaryRequest)
member.summary:
Stops the canary to prevent all future runs. If the canary is currently running, Synthetics stops waiting for the current run of the specified canary to complete. The run that is in progress completes on its own, publishes metrics, and uploads artifacts, but it is not recorded in Synthetics as a completed run.
You can use StartCanary to start it running again with the canary’s current schedule at any point in the future.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StopCanary service method.
member.returns: The response from the StopCanary service method, as returned by Synthetics.
member.exception: A conflicting operation is already in progress.
An unknown internal error occurred.

member.name: M:Amazon.Synthetics.AmazonSyntheticsClient.TagResource(Amazon.Synthetics.Model.TagResourceRequest)
member.summary:
Assigns one or more tags (key-value pairs) to the specified canary.
Tags can help you organize and categorize your resources. You can also use them to scope user permissions, by granting a user permission to access or change only resources with certain tag values.
Tags don't have any semantic meaning to Amazon Web Services and are interpreted strictly as strings of characters.
You can use the TagResource action with a canary that already has tags. If you specify a new tag key for the alarm, this tag is appended to the list of tags associated with the alarm. If you specify a tag key that is already associated with the alarm, the new tag value that you specify replaces the previous value for that tag.
You can associate as many as 50 tags with a canary.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the TagResource service method.
member.returns: The response from the TagResource service method, as returned by Synthetics.

member.name: T:Amazon.Synthetics.IAmazonSynthetics
member.summary:
Interface for accessing Synthetics
Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics
You can use Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics to continually monitor your services. You can create and manage canaries, which are modular, lightweight scripts that monitor your endpoints and APIs from the outside-in. You can set up your canaries to run 24 hours a day, once per minute. The canaries help you check the availability and latency of your web services and troubleshoot anomalies by investigating load time data, screenshots of the UI, logs, and metrics. The canaries seamlessly integrate with CloudWatch ServiceLens to help you trace the causes of impacted nodes in your applications. For more information, see Using ServiceLens to Monitor the Health of Your Applications in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.
Before you create and manage canaries, be aware of the security considerations. For more information, see Security Considerations for Synthetics Canaries.

member.name: M:Amazon.Synthetics.IAmazonSynthetics.StopCanary(Amazon.Synthetics.Model.StopCanaryRequest)
member.summary:
Stops the canary to prevent all future runs. If the canary is currently running, Synthetics stops waiting for the current run of the specified canary to complete. The run that is in progress completes on its own, publishes metrics, and uploads artifacts, but it is not recorded in Synthetics as a completed run.
You can use StartCanary to start it running again with the canary’s current schedule at any point in the future.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the StopCanary service method.
member.returns: The response from the StopCanary service method, as returned by Synthetics.
member.exception: A conflicting operation is already in progress.
An unknown internal error occurred.
One of the specified resources was not found.
A parameter could not be validated.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for StopCanary Operation

member.name: M:Amazon.Synthetics.IAmazonSynthetics.TagResource(Amazon.Synthetics.Model.TagResourceRequest)
member.summary:
Assigns one or more tags (key-value pairs) to the specified canary.
Tags can help you organize and categorize your resources. You can also use them to scope user permissions, by granting a user permission to access or change only resources with certain tag values.
Tags don't have any semantic meaning to Amazon Web Services and are interpreted strictly as strings of characters.
You can use the TagResource action with a canary that already has tags. If you specify a new tag key for the alarm, this tag is appended to the list of tags associated with the alarm. If you specify a tag key that is already associated with the alarm, the new tag value that you specify replaces the previous value for that tag.
You can associate as many as 50 tags with a canary.
member.param: Container for the necessary parameters to execute the TagResource service method.
member.returns: The response from the TagResource service method, as returned by Synthetics.
member.exception: An unknown internal error occurred.
One of the specified resources was not found.
A parameter could not be validated.
member.seealso: REST API Reference for TagResource Operation
